questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium leprae

 

Based on the ocular manifestations of leprosy, Mycobacterium leprae is the most likely causative organism.

 

  • Ocular symptoms include:
    • Lagophthalmos (inability to close the eyelids) due to the involvement of the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve. Other causes of lagophthalmos include extreme proptosis (bulging of the eyes) and symblepharon (adhesion of the eyelids to the eyeball).
    • Corneal anesthesia is due to the involvement of the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve, which innervates the cornea.
    • Corneal ulceration
    • Episcleritis
    • Iris atrophy
  • In addition, patients may present with:
    • Cataract,
    • Glaucoma,
    • Madarosis (loss of eyelashes or eyebrows)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Acanthamoeba castellanii

 

  • Acanthamoeba castellanii can cause acanthamoeba keratitis.
  • Symptoms include pain, lacrimation, photophobia, and foreign body sensation.
  • Results from direct corneal contact with infected material.
  • Contact lens users are at an increased risk.
  • Radial keratoneuritis is pathognomonic.

 

Option C: Onchocerca volvulus

 

  • Onchocerca volvulus causes onchocerciasis, commonly seen in African countries.
  • Symptoms include sclerosing keratitis, uveitis, chorioretinitis, and optic neuritis.
  • Ultimately, it can lead to optic atrophy.

 

Option D: Chlamydia A to C

 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis serovars A, B, Ba, and C are responsible for hyperendemic (blinding) trachoma.
  • The source of infection is infected conjunctival discharge.
  • If there is no secondary bacterial infection, symptoms include lacrimation, scanty mucoid discharge, and foreign body sensation.
  • Conjunctival congestion and follicles, papillary hyperplasia, Herbert follicles (seen in the limbal area), and progressive pannus are the characteristic features.
  • Serovars D to K cause neonatal and adult inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • Neonates present with conjunctival discharge, chemosis, and swollen lids.
  • Adult inclusion conjunctivitis is more commonly seen in sexually active adults and presents with foreign body sensation, mild photophobia, and mucopurulent discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lagophthalmos, orbicularis oculi palsy, and loss of corneal sensation—are indicative of neurogenic involvement, which is characteristic of leprosy, caused by Mycobacterium leprae.

questions.text: Which nutrient deficiency is cause of night blindness? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Night blindness, or nyctalopia, is a common symptom of vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is essential for the production of rhodopsin, a pigment found in the retina that is necessary for vision in low-light conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency does not typically cause night blindness. Vitamin C is important for overall health, but it is not directly involved in the visual process.

 

Option C. Vitamin B: Vitamin B deficiencies, such as vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency, can lead to various neurological symptoms but are not known to cause night blindness.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency primarily affects bone health and calcium metabolism. It is not associated with night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is commonly associated with vitamin A deficiency.

choices.text: Eye drops first, ointment 15 min later
Ointment first, eye drops 15 min later

questions.text: What is the correct order of using eye drops and eye ointment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Eye drops first, ointment 15 min later

 

To ensure proper absorption of medication, it is recommended to use eye drops before ointment. Eye drops have a thinner consistency and are absorbed more quickly, whereas ointments are thicker and need more time for absorption. Therefore, eye drops should be used first, followed by ointment after a gap of 15 minutes, especially when using both at the same time. Ointments are typically used at bedtime due to their prolonged absorption time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ointment first, eye drops 15 min later and D. Ointment first, then eye drops immediately: Incorrect because the ointment could prevent the eye drops from being absorbed properly by creating a barrier.

 

Note - Ointments are generally used last, particularly at bedtime, to maintain medication contact with the eye surface for an extended period, aiding in treatment effectiveness, especially in conditions requiring continuous exposure to the medication.

 

Option C. Eye drops first, then ointment immediately: Incorrect as applying ointment immediately after drops could interfere with the absorption of the drops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Always use eye drops before eye ointment when both forms of medication are prescribed. Allowing a gap of 15 minutes between applying drops and ointment ensures maximum effectiveness of both medications without interference in absorption.

questions.text: A patient came to the ophthalmology OPD with corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suprachoroidal hemorrhage

 

  • Suprachoroidal hemorrhage does not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient.
  • Signs of Suprachoroidal hemorrhage include the following:
  •  
    • Anterior chamber shallowing
    • Loss of the red reflex
    • Increased IOP, with firming of the eye
    • Wrinkling and bulging of the posterior capsule
    • Extrusion of intraocular contents: spontaneous nuclear expression, iris prolapse, vitreous prolapse
  • Maculopathy is a common consequence of hypotony, defined as IOP less than 5 mmHg.
  • Excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery is the most common cause of hypotonic maculopathy.
  • Other causes include trauma (cyclodialysis cleft, penetrating injury), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment.
  • Systemic causes of hypotony, usually bilateral, include dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes with hyperglycaemia, uraemia, and treatment with hyperosmotic agents or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclodialysis of uvea: This refers to the disinsertion of the ciliary body from the scleral spur, a trauma-related occurrence that can lead to a direct decrease in IOP, potentially causing hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Option C. Corneal perforation: Severe enough corneal damage, such as perforation, can lead to loss of aqueous humor and a subsequent decrease in IOP, posing a risk for hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Option D. Filtration site leak: This condition is specifically associated with glaucoma surgery where a leak at the filtration site can lead to a significant reduction in IOP, making it a direct cause of hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suprachoroidal hemorrhage does not lead to hypotonic maculopathy because it typically causes an increase in intraocular pressure, not a decrease. Understanding the distinction between conditions that increase versus those that decrease IOP is critical in the management of eye conditions and their potential complications.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presented with the following finding. What’s your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Limbal dermoid


A limbal dermoid is a benign congenital lesion often present at birth. It typically appears at the limbus, the border area between the cornea and the sclera, and is composed of dense connective tissue that can sometimes contain hair follicles or even teeth remnants.

 

The image shows a mass at the limbus, which is characteristic of a limbal dermoid. These lesions are non-cancerous and can sometimes cause astigmatism or irritation depending on their size and location.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papilloma: This option is incorrect because papillomas are epithelial tumors that usually present as small, fleshy, or warty growths on the conjunctiva. They do not typically appear as large, dense masses at the limbus.

 

Option C. Pyogenic granuloma: This is incorrect as pyogenic granulomas are fast-growing lesions that are often red, vascular, and prone to bleeding. They result from an inflammatory response and are usually not located at the limbus.

 

Option D. Pinguecula: Pingueculae are yellowish, slightly raised lesions located on the conjunctiva, usually near the nasal or temporal side of the cornea. They are associated with elastotic degeneration and do not encroach on the limbus.

 

Educational Objective:


A limbal dermoid is a congenital, benign growth located at the limbus, often containing connective tissue, hair, or teeth remnants, distinguishing it from other ocular lesions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents with a triangular, fleshy growth extending from the nasal conjunctiva onto the cornea. The lesion has gradually increased in size over the past year and causes occasional foreign body sensation. The image shows a raised, vascularized growth with the apex pointing towards the corneal center. [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pterygium

 

Explanation: 

 

The description matches pterygium, characterized by:

  • Triangular or wing-shaped fibrovascular growth
  • Extension from nasal conjunctiva onto cornea
  • Progressive growth pattern
  • Common in individuals with UV exposure (like farmers)
  • Associated symptoms of irritation and foreign body sensation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pinguecula: While also UV-related, it doesn't extend onto the cornea and remains confined to conjunctiva

 

Option C. Dermoid: Usually present since birth, round in shape, and may contain hair follicles

 

Option D. Dermolipoma: Typically located in superotemporal quadrant, soft and yellow in appearance, doesn't grow onto cornea

 

Educational Objective:

 

The location, shape, and progression pattern of ocular surface lesions are crucial diagnostic features. Pterygium's characteristic triangular shape and nasal location, combined with relevant occupational history (UV exposure), help differentiate it from other ocular surface lesions. Understanding these distinctions is essential for proper management and patient education about preventive measures.

questions.text: The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6th cranial nerve

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the 6th cranial nerve, also known as the abducens nerve. This can be remembered using the" This means that the Superior Oblique muscle is innervated by the 4th cranial nerve, the Lateral Rectus by the 6th cranial nerve, and the rest of the extraocular muscles are innervated by the 3rd cranial nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 3rd cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) innervates most of the extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique, but not the lateral rectus.

 

Option B. 4th cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 4th cranial nerve (trochlear nerve) innervates only the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option D. 7th cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve) is not involved in eye movement; it primarily controls facial muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the 6th cranial nerve (abducens nerve).

questions.text: What is the most common route of the spread of retinoblastoma? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Direct invasion

 

Direct invasion is the most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma.

Direct invasion included the optic nerve and the other parts in contact with the tumour mass. Thus, Direct invasion is a better choice. 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignancy that arises from the neurosensory retina.
  • It is the most common primary intraocular cancer in children.
  • Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

 

There are four types of retinoblastomas:

 

  1. Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye
  2. Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment
  3. Mixed type
  4. Retinocytoma: retina may be diffusely infiltrated.

 

The child is usually brought to the surgeon on account of a peculiar yellowish-white reflex from the pupil, sometimes called leukocoria or amaurotic cat's eye.

 

 

Other modes of presentation include a convergent or divergent squint, cataract, buphthalmos, hypopyon, or proptosis.

 

If left untreated, retinoblastoma runs through the following stages:

 

  • The quiescent stage: lasting from 6 months to a year.
  • The glaucomatous stage: results in enlargement of the globe, with apparent or real proptosis. Pain is severe during this stage but is relieved when the tumor bursts through the sclera.
  • The stage of extraocular extension
  • The stage of metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve invasion: While possible, it is not the most common initial route of spread but is critical once involved, as it facilitates spread to the brain.

 

Option B. Hematogenous: Represents the method for distant metastasis rather than initial local spread.

 

Option D. Lymphatic spread: Uncommon in retinoblastoma since the eye lacks significant lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct invasion is the primary method of spread for retinoblastoma is essential in recognizing how the tumor progresses and impacts surrounding ocular structures. This knowledge is crucial for effective screening, early diagnosis, and management to prevent advanced stages of disease and potential metastasis.

questions.text: Identify the finding marked by the arrow in the below image: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vossius ring

 

  • The image shows a Vossius ring, which is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity seen on the anterior surface of the lens.
  • It is caused by brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens and is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.
  • The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, producing an impression of the iris on the lens.
  • The ring usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil.
  • The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weiss ring: Is a floater which may be seen by the patient as a circle or other large solitary lesion. It is the detached former attachment to the margin of the optic disc. It is seen in posterior vitreous detachment and is not confirmatory. It is seen in the image below.

 

 

Option C. A Fleischer's ring: Is usually observed in keratoconus, representing epithelial iron deposits. It is seen best with a cobalt blue filter.

 

 

Option D. Kayser-Fleischer ring: Is observed in Wilson's disease, due to intraocular deposition of copper. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also knowns as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vossius ring is an important clinical marker of previous blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by pigment imprint from the iris on the lens surface, mirroring the size of the contracted pupil at the time of impact.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. She has a large port-wine stain on her face as shown below. The MRI of the head shows a leptomeningeal angioma. What is the most common ocular manifestation of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glaucoma

 

Glaucoma is the most common ocular manifestation of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) is a rare congenital vascular disorder characterized by facial capillary malformation (port-wine stain) and associated capillary-venous malformations affecting the brain and eye.

 

Mechanisms of glaucoma. The two main theories regarding the mechanism of glaucoma in eyes with SWS are developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle and elevated episcleral venous pressure, each of which leads to aqueous outflow restriction leading to rise in IOP. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uveitis: This is inflammation of the uvea and not a typical manifestation of SWS.

 

Option B. Retinitis pigmentosa: This is a group of genetic disorders that affect the retina's ability to respond to light, not commonly associated with SWS.

 

Option C. Keratitis: Inflammation or infection of the cornea, not linked to SWS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with Sturge-Weber syndrome, particularly those presenting with facial port-wine stains and neurological symptoms, glaucoma is a critical ocular manifestation to consider. Regular ophthalmic evaluations are essential due to the high incidence of glaucoma in these patients, focusing on managing elevated IOP to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: What is the most common tumor of the lacrimal gland? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland. This tumor is composed of a mix of ductal and myoepithelial cells, often presenting as a painless, progressive, firm mass typically located in the superolateral aspect of the orbit.

 

Details about Pleomorphic Adenoma:

 

  • Benign Nature: Despite its benign nature, pleomorphic adenoma can cause displacement of the eye and may alter vision due to its size and location.
  • Potential for Malignant Transformation: While it is primarily benign, there is a risk for malignant transformation into a carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma if not adequately treated or if left untreated for a long duration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Although this is the most common malignant tumor of the lacrimal gland, it is not as frequently occurring as pleomorphic adenoma. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known for its aggressive nature and poorer prognosis.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma: This type of tumor can involve the lacrimal gland but is generally less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Option D. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: This is another type of malignant tumor that can occur in the lacrimal gland, but it is also less common than pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland while adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the lacrimal gland. Overall, benign tumours are more common, thus pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumour.

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is shown in the image given below? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior ethmoidal nerve block

 

The procedure shown in the given image is an anterior ethmoidal nerve block.

 

The anterior ethmoidal nerve supplies the roof of the nasal cavity. It is a branch of the Nasociliary nerve which in turn is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve (V1). It is sometimes used in endonasal surgery.

 

Detailing the Procedure:

 

  • Purpose: Used predominantly to numb the area for surgical procedures within the nasal cavity.
  • Method: Involves injection near the anterior ethmoidal foramen to block the nerve that transmits sensation from the nasal roof.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nasolacrimal duct syringing: This procedure is used to check the patency of the nasolacrimal duct. It involves flushing the duct with saline to check for blockages, typically conducted by inserting a syringe into the puncta near the medial canthus of the eye. However, this is not related to the procedure shown in the image since it involves the eye directly and is performed with the eyes open to access the puncta.

 

Option C. Infraorbital nerve block: This block anesthetizes the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve, which affects the lower eyelid, upper lip, and cheek. It is generally performed via an intraoral approach at the infraorbital foramen, located below the orbit, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Option D. Trephination of the frontal sinus: This surgical procedure involves making an incision in the floor of the frontal sinus to facilitate drainage. This procedure targets a different anatomic location and involves surgical tools, not the approach shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An anterior ethmoidal nerve block is crucial for numbing the nasal cavity area, particularly in endonasal surgeries. It is essential for procedures requiring detailed work near the roof of the nasal cavity, reflecting the significance of understanding the specific nerve anatomy for effective anesthesia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of recurrent sinusitis presents with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever. A computed tomography (CT) scan was done. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis

 

Involves the contents of the orbit including fat and muscle, often secondary to sinus infections, particularly the ethmoid sinus.

 

Symptoms include painful eye movements, protrusion of the eyeball (proptosis), decreased vision, and fever.

 

This condition can be sight-threatening and requires urgent treatment.

 

  • For the 35-year-old male patient with a history of recurrent sinusitis presenting with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever, the diagnosis of Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is most consistent with the symptoms and the findings on the computed tomography (CT) scan. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preseptal Cellulitis with Sinusitis: Involves the eyelid and skin anterior to the orbital septum, typically without eye protrusion or vision changes.Fever and eyelid swelling are common, but the involvement of the eye as described suggests a deeper infection.

 

Option C. Subperiosteal Abscess: This is an accumulation of pus between the orbit and the periosteum of the orbital bones, typically a complication of orbital cellulitis. It may lead to eye protrusion and restricted eye movements, but it's typically identified on imaging as a distinct abscess rather than generalized infection signs.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: A broad term that can refer to any soft tissue infection but without specifying involvement of the orbital area in relation to the sinuses would be less specific compared to orbital cellulitis with sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent complications such as vision loss, intracranial spread of infection, and other severe outcomes.

questions.text: Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capsulorrhexis

 

  • Capsulorrhexis is a step in the conventional extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) method.
  • It is a method of anterior capsulotomy, where an opening is made in the anterior capsule of the lens.
  • Anterior capsulotomy can be done by 3 methods:
    1. Can-opener's technique
    2. Linear capsulotomy or envelope technique
    3. Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis
  • Continuous curvilinear capsulorrhexis (CCC) is considered superior because it does not leave any edges or tears when done correctly.
  • Trypan blue dye can be used to stain the lens capsule for better visibility during the procedure.
  • In ECCE, a portion of the anterior capsule of the lens is removed, allowing extraction of the lens nucleus and cortex while leaving the remainder of the anterior capsule, the posterior capsule, and the zonular support intact.
  • After capsulorrhexis, hydro dissection is performed using a balanced salt solution to separate the corticonuclear mass from the capsule.
  • Removal of lens nucleus and aspiration of the cortex is done using a two-way irrigation and aspiration cannula.
  • An intraocular lens (IOL) is then implanted, and the incision is closed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrodissection: Hydrodissection involves injecting fluid under the anterior capsule to separate the lens nucleus from the cortex and the capsule. This procedure follows capsulorrhexis and serves to facilitate the removal of the lens material. The image does not show fluid injection or the separation process typical of hydrodissection.

 

Option C. Intraocular lens implantation: This step involves placing an intraocular lens (IOL) into the capsular bag once the lens material has been removed. In the image, there is no indication of an IOL being handled or inserted, as the focus is solely on manipulating the capsule itself, which precedes the IOL implantation in the surgical sequence.

 

Option D. Lens aspiration: Lens aspiration involves the removal of the lens cortex and nucleus, usually through suction or phacoemulsification, following the capsulorrhexis and hydrodissection steps. The image does not depict any equipment or actions associated with the aspiration of lens material, such as a phacoemulsification handpiece or suction device.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capsulorrhexis is characterized by the creation of a controlled and continuous tear in the anterior capsule of the lens, which is essential for accessing and removing the lens material in cataract surgery. This method provides a clear opening without leaving jagged edges, which is crucial for the structural integrity of the remaining capsule necessary for IOL placement.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with a yellow question mark ? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inner nuclear layer

 

The marked structure in the slide is the inner nuclear layer of the retina

 

  • Present between the outer plexiform layer and the inner plexiform layer.
  • Contains the cell bodies of bipolar cells, horizontal cells, and amacrine cells.
  • Dark stain.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presents with endophthalmitis 5 days after cataract surgery. All of the following treatments can be used, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous steroids

 

  • Intravenous steroids are not used for the treatment of endophthalmitis.
  • Endophthalmitis is an intraocular inflammation affecting the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber.
  • Etiology: exogenous infection (trauma, surgery), endogenous or metastatic endophthalmitis, secondary infections from surrounding structures.
  • Cardinal features: pain, lid swelling, diminished vision.
  • Maintain high index of suspicion, especially in postoperative cases, and treat empirically with antibiotics and steroids from the beginning.

 

Treatment

 

All cases are treated empirically with a combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics and corticosteroids from the beginning. The aim is to maintain a high intraocular concentration of antibiotics throughout treatment.

 

  • Therapeutic regimen 
    • Topical antibiotics: Fortified cefazolin or vancomycin with gentamicin or amikacin.
    • Topical atropine: for cycloplegia.
    • Subconjunctival antibiotics: not frequently used.
    • Intravitreal antibiotics: The treatment of choice and are injected after taking vitreous aspirate for preparing smears and obtaining cultures. A combination of vancomycin and ceftazidime is preferred. Amikacin or gentamicin is used less frequently (risk of macular infarction). Simultaneous injection of dexamethasone is optional.
    • Intravitreal injection of amphotericin B: In suspected fungal aetiology, without the use of any adjunctive steroids.
    • Oral antifungals: Given, if fungal cultures are positive.
    • Vitrectomy: Hastens bacterial and fungal endophthalmitis recovery.
    • Corticosteroids: 
      • Some authorities recommend the combined use of corticosteroids from the outset (unless there is a strong clinical suspicion of a fungal aetiology in which case steroids should be withheld), while others prefer to wait for a confirmed positive clinical response to antibiotic therapy before administering steroids over the next 24–48 hours.
      • The rationale for corticosteroid therapy derives from its anti-inflammatory effects, leading to preservation of the ocular structures.
      • Routes of administration are:
        1. Intravitreal injection of dexamethasone
        2. Subconjunctival injection of dexamethasone
        3. Topical dexamethasone or predacetate
        4. Oral prednisolone
    • Patients need to be reviewed every 4–8 hours. The visual outcome depends on the duration between the onset of infection and institution of therapy, and the nature of the infecting organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A Intravitreal antibiotic injection: This is a standard treatment for endophthalmitis, involving direct administration of antibiotics into the eye to quickly achieve high intraocular concentrations, crucial for combating the infection.

 

Option C. Pars plana vitrectomy: Often recommended for severe cases, this surgical intervention can remove infectious agents and inflammatory debris directly from the vitreous, thereby reducing bacterial load and improving drug penetration.

 

Option D. Topical antibiotic: Used to provide high local concentrations of antibiotics at the site of infection, though not sufficient alone for severe cases, they support the main treatment regimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For endophthalmitis following ocular surgery, intravitreal antibiotics are crucial, while systemic steroids are generally avoided due to the risk of exacerbating the infection.

questions.text: All are causes for expanding blind spot, except? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoplasia of optic disc

 

Expansion of blind spot is not seen in optic disc hypoplasia. Optic nerve hypoplasia is the most common congenital optic disc anomaly that presents due to the underdevelopment of the optic nerve. The optic disc is surrounded by a yellowish pigmented ring known as a "double-ring" sign. This condition does not typically lead to changes in the size of the blind spot, as it primarily affects the development of the optic nerve rather than its function related to the blind spot's expansion.

 

 

  • Physiological blind spot is an area of absolute scotoma caused by the absence of photoreceptors in the region occupied by the optic disc.
  • Lesions affecting the optic disc region can expand the blind spot.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. POAG: The rise in IOP in primary open-angle glaucoma causes pressure on the optic nerve head and consequent atrophy leading to expansion of the blindspot.

 

Option C. Papilledema: Papilledema is a passive disc swelling associated with raised intracranial pressure, and the edematous optic disc is swollen beyond its usual margins, causing the blind spot to enlarge.

 

Option D. Medullated nerve fibres: Medullated nerve fibers (optic disc medullation) is a condition of abnormal myelination of the nerve fibers of the retina, where myelination continues beyond lamina cribrosa and spreads into the retina beyond the optic disc. This leads to the expansion of the blind spot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic disc hypoplasia, a congenital underdevelopment of the optic nerve, does not typically result in an expanding blind spot, unlike conditions like POAG, papilledema, and the presence of medullated nerve fibers, which can directly affect the structure or function of the area surrounding the optic disc.

questions.text: SAFE strategy for trachoma includes all except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Evaluation of control program

 

In the SAFE strategy, ‘E’ stands for Environmental improvement with better hygiene and sanitation.

 

Effective interventions for trachoma blindness have been demonstrated in developing nations using the SAFE strategy –

 

  • Surgery (S): Performed to correct trichiasis, which is the inward turning of the eyelashes that can lead to corneal damage and blindness. This intervention helps prevent further damage to the cornea.
  • Antibiotics (A): Used to treat the infection caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. Mass drug administration is typically used in endemic areas to reduce the prevalence of the infection.
  • Facial cleanliness (F): Encouraged to reduce transmission of the bacterium among community members, especially children who are more susceptible to infection.
  • Environmental improvement (E): Focuses on improving living conditions, such as increasing access to clean water and better sanitation facilities, to reduce the spread of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient came to OPD with the complaints of glare during night drives. He had undergone cataract surgery 1 year back. The best-corrected visual acuity in RE = 6/12 and LE = 6/9. No improvement with pinhole. What is the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior capsular opacification

 

Posterior capsular Opacification is a common complication that can occur after cataract surgery. It is also known as "after" or "secondary" cataract. The condition is caused by residual opaque lens matter that may persist after surgery or by the proliferative type that develops from left-out anterior epithelial cells.

 

 

The surgery usually involves the removal of the lens through a small incision in the cornea. In extracapsular extraction of the lens, the posterior capsule and part of the anterior capsule are left in situ. In many cases, these remnants are fine, forming a thin membrane that is difficult to see. However, in some cases, especially when the cataract was not mature, some soft, clear cortex sticks to the capsule.

 

Posterior capsular pacification can present in different forms, including thickened posterior capsule, dense membranous after cataract or Soemmering's ring, or Elschnig's pearls. Soemmering's ring refers to a thick ring of after cataract formed behind the iris, enclosed between the two layers of capsule. Elschnig's pearls refer to vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells clustered like soap bubbles along the posterior capsule.

 

 

If the remnants lie in the pupillary area, they can form a dense membrane that impairs vision. This membranous form of posterior capsular Opacification can cause vision to be blurry, hazy, or cloudy. If the previous operation has been followed by iritis, exudates also adhere to the lens remnants and organize, thus contributing a fibrous membrane in addition.

 

The rate of posterior capsule Opacification varies with the patient's age, surgeon, surgical technique, type of intraocular lens used, and duration after surgery. Patients who are younger and those who undergo phacoemulsification may have a lower risk of developing posterior capsular Opacification.

 

Overall, posterior capsular Opacification is a treatable condition that can be resolved through a simple laser procedure called Nd YAG Laser posterior capsulotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cystoid macular edema: This involves swelling in the central retina and is often associated with decreased vision and possibly distorted central vision, not primarily glare.

 

Option B. Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy: This condition involves swelling and opacities in the cornea following cataract surgery, characterized by significant visual impairment and painful blisters on the cornea, not just glare.

 

Option C. ARMD - Age-Related Macular Degeneration: ARMD affects the macula and leads to central vision loss, which would not typically present primarily as glare or be directly associated with recent cataract surgery outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior capsular opacification after cataract surgery can mimic the symptoms of the original cataract and cause significant visual impairment, primarily glare and blurred vision. It is treatable with a simple laser procedure known as Nd YAG laser posterior capsulotomy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male, employed as a welder, presents with the following eye symptoms: pain, redness, and excessive tearing. What would be the appropriate next step in managing this condition?(FMGE Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Remove with 26G needle

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of foreign body in the eye. Removal of the foreign body using a 26G needle is the next step in the management of this patient.

 

  • Foreign bodies must be removed as soon as possible.
  • The removal technique depends on the location and nature of the foreign body.
    1. Lying loose in the lower fornix: Evert the lower lid and remove with a clean swab.
    2. The upper lid (sulcus subtarsalis): Evert and double evert with a Desmarres retractor, if required then remove with a clean swab. In case of difficulty, anaesthetize the conjunctival sac.
    3. Embedded in the bulbar conjunctiva: Remove with a foreign body spud or fine forceps under topical anaesthesia. A disposable sterile hypodermic needle may also be used.
    4. The cornea: Remove using the slit lamp or operating microscope. Anaesthetize the eye and hold the lids apart with the first and second fingers of your left hand, pressing slightly backwards so as to steady the globe.
  • First attempt to remove the foreign body by dislodging it with a sterilized spud.
  • If repeated efforts fail, a disposable hypodermic (26 or 27 gauge) needle should be used.
  • The greatest care should be taken not to scrape the epithelium more than is absolutely necessary.
  • In all cases: an antibiotic ointment should be applied and the eye kept bandaged for a day.
  • Particles of stone show a greater tendency than metal to cause infective ulceration, probably because metallic particles are often hot and therefore sterile when they enter the eye.
  • Occasionally, sharp steel and other particles penetrate deep into the cornea without perforating it. The efforts made to remove them may push them deeper or even into the anterior chamber. Special precautions should be taken if such a scenario is suspected.
  • If the particle is magnetizable, magnetic removal should be tried, but it is usually necessary to incise the cornea overlying the foreign body. However, this method may fail, particularly if the particle is small and in case the particle enters the AC, it has to be removed by other methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syringing and washing: This is not typically used for embedded foreign bodies and is more appropriate for chemical injuries or superficial debris.

 

Option B. Antibiotics and steroids: While antibiotics are used post-removal to prevent infection, steroids are not the primary treatment for foreign body removal.

 

Option C. Keratoplasty: This is a surgical procedure for corneal transplants and is not indicated for foreign body removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of a corneal foreign body, especially in an occupational setting like welding, involves careful removal using a sterile hypodermic needle, followed by the application of antibiotic ointment to prevent infection.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causing acute bacterial conjunctivitis is NOT associated with a Polymorphonuclear response?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Moraxella lacunata

 

Explanation:

 

Moraxella lacunata, although a causative agent of bacterial conjunctivitis, does not evoke a significant polymorphonuclear (PMN) response in the conjunctiva. This distinguishes it from other common bacterial pathogens of conjunctivitis, which typically provoke a robust PMN response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcus aureus: Commonly causes acute bacterial conjunctivitis, characterized by a significant PMN response.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: Also causes bacterial conjunctivitis with a notable PMN response.

 

Option D. Streptococcus pneumoniae: Typically leads to bacterial conjunctivitis with a pronounced PMN response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Moraxella lacunata does not evoke a significant polymorphonuclear response in the conjunctiva, unlike other common bacterial causes of conjunctivitis.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿ETDRS chart - Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study

questions.text: Identify the chart given in the picture below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hess chart

 

  • Hess chart is a diagnostic tool used to assess the field of a binocular single vision.
  • It is used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus.
  • Incomitant strabismus is a type of squint that occurs due to the limitation of eye movement associated with paralytic or mechanical etiologies.
  • The chart consists of a smaller chart that indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart that indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.
  • The field of binocular single vision is the area where bifoveal fusion of an object of interest occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The Snellen chart is used to test visual acuity. Visual acuity is the eye's ability to discriminate between two points.

 

A picture of the Snellen chart is given below.

 

 

Option C: The Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart consists of letters of constant size but decreasing contrast. It is viewed by the patient from a distance of 1 meter until the lowest resolvable group of three letters on the chart is reached. It is used to measure contrast sensitivity, a measure of the ability to distinguish an object against its background. An image of the Pelli-Robson chart used in the Middle East is given below.

 

 

Option D: The early treatment diabetic retinopathy study or ETDRS chart presents a series of 5 letters of equal difficulty on each row, with standardized spacing between letters and rows. It consists of a total of 14 lines having 70 letters. It is also used to test visual acuity. An image of the ETDRS chart is given below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hess chart is specifically designed to assess binocular vision and ocular muscle function, especially useful in diagnosing and managing strabismus and similar conditions affecting eye alignment and movement.

questions.text: The spectacles shown in the image are not used for the management of which of the following? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypermetropia

 

The image shows a bifocal spectacle that is made of lenses with two different optical powers (upper half for distant vision and lower half for near vision). Hypermetropia, or farsightedness, primarily affects near vision, necessitating correction that provides a uniform optical adjustment across the entire lens surface to assist with close vision tasks, rather than segmented correction like in bifocals.

 

Other Options:

 

Bifocal spectacles are typically used for treating following conditions:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bifocal spectacles are not typically used for treating hypermetropia, which generally requires a uniform optical correction across the entire lens to aid in near tasks. Bifocals are instead beneficial in conditions requiring simultaneous correction for near and far vision, such as presbyopia, or specific needs following surgical interventions like in aphakia and pediatric pseudophakia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of sudden onset ocular pain and haemorrhagic discharge accompanied with diminution of vision. He is suspected to have acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis. What is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Enterovirus 70

 

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by enterovirus 70, a picornavirus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterovirus 68: Known to cause respiratory illnesses and has been associated with acute flaccid myelitis, but not typically with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Enterovirus 69: Less commonly associated with conjunctivitis and more related to respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Enterovirus 71: Known to cause hand, foot, and mouth disease and severe neurological diseases, but not typically associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterovirus 70 is the primary causative organism of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, characterized by sudden onset of ocular pain, redness, and hemorrhagic discharge. The condition is highly contagious and typically self-limiting, with supportive care being the mainstay of treatment.

choices.text: Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Medial rectus > Inferior rectus
Medial rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Inferior rectus
Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus
Superior rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Medial rectus

questions.text: What is the correct order of insertion of muscles from near to far from the limbus?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

 

This order represents the correct sequence of insertion of the extraocular muscles from near to far from the limbus, which is the border between the cornea and the sclera of the eye. The medial rectus inserts closest to the limbus, around 5.5mm, followed by the inferior rectus, which inserts at 6.5mm; the lateral rectus at 6.9mm and the superior rectus inserts farthest from the limbus, which is 7.7mm. The spiral formed by joining the insertion points of the four recti muscles is referred to as the Spiral of Tillaux

 

 

  • Medial rectus: This muscle is located closest to the limbus among the options provided. It inserts on the sclera of the eye near the medial aspect.
  • Inferior rectus: Following the medial rectus, the inferior rectus muscle inserts on the sclera near the lower aspect of the eye, hence moving away from the limbus.
  • Lateral rectus: Next in the sequence is the lateral rectus muscle, which inserts on the lateral aspect of the sclera, farther away from the limbus compared to the medial and inferior rectus muscles.
  • Superior rectus: Lastly, the superior rectus muscle inserts on the sclera near the upper aspect of the eye, making it farthest from the limbus among the muscles listed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of insertion of the extraocular muscles from near to far from the limbus is: Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

questions.text: Identify the lesion in the histopathological image of retina: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Drusen  

 

  • Drusen, also called colloid bodies, are extracellular deposits located at the interface between the Retinal Pigmentary Epithelium and Bruch membrane.
  • Drusen are numerous, minute, whitish, refractile spots with pigmented margins, mainly involving the posterior pole.
  • They are seen in senile macular degeneration and Doyne's honeycomb dystrophy.
  • The material of which they are composed has a broad range of constituents and is thought to be derived from immune-mediated and metabolic processes in the retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  • The precise role of drusen in the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is unclear.
  • However, drusen are positively associated with the size of lesions and the presence or absence of associated pigmentary abnormalities.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hard exudates: Well-defined, bright yellow deposits of extravasated fluid rich in fibrin and proteins. These hyaline or lipid deposits are generally seen as a cluster around a group of leaking microaneurysms. Commonly seen in macular area, in the outer plexiform layer.

 

Option C. Cotton-wool spots: Composed of accumulations of neuronal debris within the nerve fibre layer.

 

Option D. Macular edema: Accumulation of excess fluid in the extracellular space within the retina in the macular area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drusen are distinct, granular deposits at the interface between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch's membrane, commonly associated with age-related macular degeneration and can be an early sign of the disease.

questions.text: Which surgical procedure should a 21-year-old boxer avoid to maintain optimal visual health? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RK

 

  • For a 21-year-old boxer who needs to maintain optimal visual health, understanding the differences between various refractive surgeries is crucial. 

 

Involves making radial cuts in the cornea to change its shape and correct refractive errors. It's not recommended for boxers because it weakens the structural integrity of the eye, making it more vulnerable to trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PRK (Photorefractive Keratectomy): This surgery involves removing the surface layer of the cornea to reshape it with a laser. It is safer than RK for athletes because it does not involve creating a flap, which could dislocate upon impact, though recovery can be slower.

 

Option C. LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis): LASIK surgery also reshapes the cornea but through creating a thin flap in the outer layer. While popular due to quick recovery times and immediate results, the flap might pose a risk in contact sports, as it could dislodge or move from direct impact.

 

Option D. SMILE (Small Incision Lenticule Extraction): The newest form of laser eye surgery, SMILE involves making a small, lenticule-shaped cut inside the cornea to reshape it without creating a flap. It offers a potentially safer option for athletes as it maintains more of the cornea's structural integrity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For a boxer, avoiding procedures that compromise the cornea's physical integrity is crucial due to the high risk of impacts to the face. Among these options, RK and potentially LASIK present higher risks. SMILE or PRK might be safer alternatives, providing effective vision correction with a reduced risk of severe complications from physical trauma.

questions.text: Following instrument is used to measure: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proptosis

 

The image shows a Hertel exophthalmometer, which is specifically designed to measure proptosis—the forward displacement of the eye. 

 

This instrument directly measures how much the eyeball protrudes forward from the eye socket. It is essential in diagnosing conditions like thyroid eye disease where proptosis is a common feature.

 

  • Design and Use: It consists of a ruler and two lateral mirrors or prisms that align with the lateral orbital rim, allowing for accurate measurement of the anterior position of the cornea relative to the lateral orbital wall.
    1. Bilateral Assessment: The Hertel exophthalmometer can measure the protrusion of both eyes simultaneously, allowing for comparison between the two. This is vital for identifying asymmetrical proptosis, which can be an indicator of more serious unilateral orbital disease.
    2. Quantitative Data: It provides quantitative data that can help in monitoring the progression or resolution of orbital diseases over time. This is particularly useful in tracking the effectiveness of treatment for conditions that cause proptosis.
    3. Simple and Non-invasive: The device is straightforward to use and non-invasive, making it a patient-friendly tool for regular follow-up assessments in clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Hertel exophthalmometer is a specialized tool for assessing the extent of proptosis in conditions affecting the orbit and surrounding tissues, helping guide further diagnostic and therapeutic steps for conditions like thyroid eye disease.

questions.text: A patient of rheumatic heart disease who is noncompliant with treatment presents with complaints of superior field vision loss for the past 1 week. What is the probable cause of the given condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Branched retinal vein occlusion (BRVO)

 

A patient with rheumatic heart disease is at an increased risk of thromboembolic events, which can affect the retinal vessels. The key features presented are a history of superior field vision loss over the past week, which suggests a gradual onset typical of venous occlusion rather than arterial occlusion.

 

Key Features of BRVO:

 

  • Gradual onset: BRVO often presents with gradual vision changes, which is consistent with the patient's history of vision loss over one week.
  • Superior field vision loss: Indicates that the inferior retinal quadrant is affected, as retinal involvement typically causes a visual field defect in the opposite quadrant.
  • Associated with thromboembolic phenomena: Patients with rheumatic heart disease have a higher risk of thromboembolic events, leading to BRVO.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branched retinal artery occlusion (BRAO): BRAO typically presents with a sudden onset of vision loss due to an acute blockage in the retinal artery. It is less common and would present immediately rather than over a week.

 

Option B. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO): CRAO causes a sudden, painless, and profound loss of vision, not a gradual superior field vision loss.

 

Option D. Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO)

 

CRVO generally leads to a more severe, diffuse loss of vision, not limited to a specific field. It also typically presents with sudden vision loss rather than the gradual progression described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRVO is the most probable cause of superior field vision loss in a patient with rheumatic heart disease due to its association with thromboembolic events and gradual onset of symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia increases on dextroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right superior rectus

 

  • The clinical scenario described is due to right superior rectus palsy.
  • The three-step test, also called the Parks-Bielschowsky three-step test, can help diagnose which muscle is paralyzed in acquired hypertropia. It involves using the cover-uncover test and Maddox rod to measure deviation in different head positions.
  • The three-step test can also diagnose inferior oblique or vertical rectus muscle palsy, but it's not reliable for multiple paretic muscles or restrictive strabismus.
  • In patients with inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist, the three-step test can distinguish between true or simulated superior rectus palsy.

 

Using the three-step test in the above clinical scenario:

 

Step 1. Which eye is hypotropic?

 

The eye hypotropic in the primary position is the right eye. The paretic muscles can be right eye elevator or left eye depressor.

 

  • Right superior rectus
  • Right inferior oblique
  • Left inferior rectus
  • Left superior oblique

 

Step 2. Does the hypotropia increase in the right gaze or left gaze?

 

The hypotropia increases in right gaze.

 

Therefore, the paretic muscle must be either (1) one of the muscles whose primary action is elevating the right eye on the right gaze, or (2) one of the muscles whose primary action is depressing the left eye in the right gaze. The left inferior oblique and the right superior rectus both have a primary action of elevation in right gaze. Therefore, one of these muscles could be the paretic muscle. Likewise, the left superior oblique and the right inferior rectus have a primary action of depression in the right gaze and could be paretic. But since the left inferior oblique and the right inferior rectus did not meet step 1, they can be eliminated from the possible paretic muscles. This leaves us:

 

  • Left superior oblique
  • Right superior rectus

 

Step 3. Does the hypotropia increase in the right head tilt or left head tilt?

 

The hypotropia increases in the right head tilt. If the deviation increases on right head tilt and decreases on left head tilt, as it does in this example patient, then the right superior rectus is implicated as the paretic culprit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right superior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis typically leads to hypertropia and excyclotorsion, not hypotropia.

 

Option C. Right inferior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis would not result in the described pattern of hypotropia.

 

Option D. Left inferior oblique: Incorrect, since paralysis here does not explain the increase in hypotropia with right head tilt and right gaze.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three-step test is a vital diagnostic tool in strabismus evaluations to identify which extraocular muscle is paretic based on the changes in eye position with head tilt and gaze direction. In this scenario, the findings align with a right superior rectus muscle palsy, consistent with its role in elevating the right eye especially during right gaze and head tilt to the right.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the eye: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Canal of Petit

 

Canal of Petit, aka Spatia Zonularis / Zonular spaces, is a cleft or sacculated canal surrounding the lens between the posterior of the zonule of Zinn fibers and aqueous humor.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Egger's Line: This is a reference line used in gonioscopy to denote the anterior limit of the trabecular meshwork, not directly related to the lens or zonular apparatus.

 

Option B. Lens Capsule: This is the clear, membrane-like structure surrounding the lens itself, not the space around it.

 

Option C. Canal of Hannover: This is another anatomical feature in the eye associated with the zonular fibers but refers to a different part of the zonular apparatus than the Canal of Petit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Canal of Petit is an essential structure in the anatomy of the eye, playing a critical role in the stability and function of the lens. Its correct identification and understanding are pivotal in eye health management and surgical procedures involving the lens and surrounding structures.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism. What would be the appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Spherical equivalent spectacles

 

The appropriate management for myopic astigmatism in a 15-year-old girl (<18 years) would be spherical equivalent spectacles.

 

The three components of prescription in astigmatism are:

 

  • Power of the spherical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre sphere (DS)
  • Power of the cylindrical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre cylinder (DC)
  • Axis or orientation of the cylinder.

 

The cylindrical power and axis are correcting the astigmatic part of the refractive error. If an astigmatic eye were to be corrected with a spherical lens alone, the result would be a blur circle on the retina, called the circle of least confusion.

 

The spherical lens power places the circle of least confusion on the retina and is called the spherical equivalent. It is defined as the spherical power whose focal point coincides with the circle of least confusion, where one would see minimal blurring in their vision.
 

 

For example, for spherical power is +2 and cylindrical power is +3,

Spherical equivalent = +2.00 +(+3.00 /2) = +3.50.

 

Spherical equivalent spectacles are given if one has to give less cylinder power than was measured.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. and C - LASIK and Femto LASIK: should be done in patients above 18 years of age.

 

Option D. Implantable Collamer lens: is indicated for patients 21-45 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical interventions like LASIK and Femto LASIK are not recommended for individuals under 18 years of age.

choices.text: Regeneration is limited to the limbus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about corneal epithelium? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bowman's membrane regenerates.

 

The false statement about the corneal epithelium is B, stating that "Bowman's membrane regenerates." This is incorrect as Bowman's membrane is an acellular layer composed of collagen fibers and, once damaged, does not regenerate. The other statements regarding the corneal epithelium are true and align with the anatomical and functional characteristics of the cornea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Regeneration is limited to the limbus: This is true as limbal stem cells are key to the regeneration of the corneal epithelium.

 

Option C. Lined by stratified squamous epithelium: True, this describes the specific cell type forming the corneal epithelium.

 

Option D. Apical cells have microvilli: Also true, the microvilli increase the surface area for better adhesion of the tear film, enhancing eye lubrication and protection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thyroid ophthalmopathy

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state.
  • TED may be associated with Graves’ disease, hypothyroidism, or euthyroidism, and the direct causative connection between thyroid dysfunction and ocular changes is unclear.
  • Main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital pseudotumor: Presents with painful eye movements, periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia.

 

Option C. Orbital lymphoma: Usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

 

Option D. Orbital cellulitis: Is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

 

NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

THYROID OPHTHALMOPATHY EYE SIGNS:

  1. Stellwag sign- incomplete and frequent blinking
  2. Gifford sign- difficulty while everting the upper eyelid
  3. Jellinek sign- abnormal pigmentation of upper eyelid
  4. Enroth sign- lower eyelid edema
  5. Griffith sign- lid lag on upgaze
  6. Mobius sign- not able to converge eyes
  7. Ballet's sign- one or more extraocular muscle restriction
  8. Von graefe sign- retarded descent of upper lid in downgaze
  9. Joffrey sign- absent crease of the forehead in superior gaze
  10. Kocher's sign- staring and frightened appearance of eyes
  11. Dalyrymple sign- eyelid retraction

questions.text: Which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most likely to be observed in a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2020
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Marcus Gunn pupil  

 

  • Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nerve damage.
  • A defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye can cause a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test.
  • The Marcus Gunn pupil is observed when the flashlight is moved from the normal to the abnormal eye and the affected pupil dilates instead of remaining constricted.
  • Seen in optic neuritis.
  • Earliest indictor of optic nerve disease (Retrobulbar neuritis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adie tonic pupil is a Sluggishly reacting mid-dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

 

Option C. Argyll-Robertson pupils (AR pupils) are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation, which is a specific sign in neurosyphilis and is due to a lesion in the pretectal nucleus.

 

Option D. Hutchinson's pupil is a clinical sign where the pupil on the side of an intracranial mass lesion is dilated and unreactive to light, due to compression of the oculomotor nerve on that side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marcus Gunn pupil, or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), is an important clinical sign in primary open-angle glaucoma, indicating asymmetric optic nerve damage, and is identified using the swinging flashlight test.

questions.text:
Which of the following has familial inheritance? (INICET May 2022)

 

  1. Retinoblastoma
  2. Retinitis pigmentosa
  3. Муоріа
  4. Primary open angle glaucoma
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

All the above conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) have a familial inheritance.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma, Retinitis pigmentosa, Myopia, and Primary open-angle glaucoma — exhibit familial inheritance patterns, meaning they can be passed down through families, indicating genetic influences.

questions.text: Name the location of the nucleus supplying the muscle marked with the question mark in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superior colliculus

 

The highlighted muscle is the medial rectus, which is supplied by the oculomotor nerve. The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve is situated at the level of the superior colliculus. The oculomotor nerve arises from a nuclear complex that includes the oculomotor nucleus and Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus. The oculomotor nucleus is comprised of several groups of large motor neurons that innervate the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus in dorsoventral order. Additionally, a column of cells located medially innervates the contralateral superior rectus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior olivary: This is part of the auditory pathway and has no involvement in eye muscle control.

 

Option B. Inferior colliculus: Also part of the auditory pathway, located in the midbrain but not involved in motor control of eye movements.

 

Option D. Fascial colliculus: This term is likely a typographical error for "facial colliculus," which refers to a structure in the brainstem associated with the facial nerve, not the oculomotor nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve, responsible for innervating the medial rectus muscle among others, is located at the level of the superior colliculus in the midbrain. This is crucial for understanding the neural control of eye movements, particularly in how various components of the eye are coordinated for proper visual alignment and focus.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the given image? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6th nerve palsy

 

  • The left eye of the patient has limitation of movement laterally.
  • The sixth cranial nerve innervates the lateral rectus. In case of lateral rectus palsy,
    • ﻿﻿There is a convergent squint with limitation of movement outwards, and the face is turned towards the paralysed side.
    • ﻿﻿Homonymous diplopia occurs on looking to the paralysed side.
    • ﻿﻿The images are on the same level and erect, becoming more separated on looking more towards the paralysed side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve palsy:

 

  • Oculomotor nerve supplies all intraocular muscles (sphincter and dilator pupillae) and extraocular muscles (LPS, MR, SR, IR, IO) except lateral rectus and superior oblique.
  • Its paralysis results in
    • Ptosis - Due to the paralysis of LPS
    • Down and out eye (due to unopposed lateral rectus and superior oblique)
    • Loss of accommodation (due to paralysis of ciliary muscle)
    • Loss of light reflex
    • Dilated pupil
    • Crossed diplopia

 

Option C. Bell’s palsy:

 

  • Bell palsy is the most common cause of peripheral facial palsy.

 

 

Option D. Horner’s syndrome:

 

  • Sympathetic denervation of face:
    • Ptosis (slight drooping of eyelid: superior tarsal muscle)
    • Miosis (pupil constriction)
    • Anhidrosis (absence of sweating)
    • Flushing of affected side of face

 

Educational Objective:

 

6th nerve palsy is characterized by an inability to abduct the eye, typically presenting as inward turning of the eye due to unopposed medial rectus action, leading to horizontal diplopia that worsens when looking towards the side of the affected nerve. This diagnosis is crucial in patients presenting with lateral gaze limitation following trauma, raised intracranial pressure, or an ischemic event.

questions.text: Patient can see 3 green dots on the Worth’s 4 dots test. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) RE suppression

 

The Worth 4-dot test is used to evaluate binocular vision and identify suppression of one eye or diplopia. The patient wears red-green goggles where the Red lens is over the Right eye (RE) and the green lens is over the left eye (LE). Normally, a person should see four dots: one red, two green, and one white dot that appears either as red, green, or mixed (brown), depending on which eye is dominant or if both eyes are functioning equally.

 

If a patient sees only three green dots, it indicates suppression of the right eye (RE). This is because the right eye, which should see the red dot, is not contributing to the vision, leading the patient to perceive only the green dots seen by the left eye.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crossed diplopia: In crossed diplopia, images from the right eye appear on the left side and vice versa, causing overlapping images. This does not match the scenario where only three green dots are seen.

 

 

Option B. Uncrossed diplopia: Uncrossed diplopia occurs when images appear on the same side as the eye seeing them. It would involve seeing more dots (double vision) rather than missing a dot due to suppression.

 

 

Option D. LE suppression: Left eye suppression would result in the patient seeing only two red dots, as the left eye is not contributing to the vision. This does not match the observed scenario of seeing three green dots.

 

Educational Objective:


Seeing three green dots on the Worth 4-dot test indicates right eye suppression (RE suppression), as the right eye is not seeing the red dot.

questions.text: What event takes place when the retina is exposed to light? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperpolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release

 

The retina responds to light by initiating a process called phototransduction, which converts light energy into an electrical signal. This process involves the activation of rods and cones, which are the photoreceptor cells in the retina.

 

In the dark, the cGMP gated channels in the photoreceptor cells are open, allowing a steady release of neurotransmitters such as glutamate. However, when light falls on the retina, a series of biochemical reactions occur, leading to the conversion of 11-cis-retinal to all-trans-retinal. This process activates transducin, which is a G protein-coupled receptor with phosphodiesterase activity, resulting in the breakdown of cGMP. As a result of the decrease in cGMP levels, sodium channels close, causing hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor cell.

 

The hyperpolarization leads to a decrease in glutamate release, which ultimately triggers the formation of an action potential. This process enables the transmission of visual information from the photoreceptor cells to the brain, allowing us to perceive and interpret visual images.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperpolarization, increase in neurotransmitter release: This is incorrect because hyperpolarization of photoreceptor cells leads to a decrease, not an increase, in neurotransmitter release.

 

Option C. Depolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release: This is incorrect because light exposure causes hyperpolarization, not depolarization, of photoreceptor cells.

 

Option D. Depolarization, increase in neurotransmitter release: This is also incorrect as it suggests the opposite response of photoreceptors to light. Depolarization and increased neurotransmitter release occur in the absence of light (i.e., in the dark).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Light exposure results in the hyperpolarization of photoreceptor cells in the retina, leading to a decrease in the release of the neurotransmitter glutamate. This process is crucial for converting light signals into electrical signals that can be processed by the brain to form visual images.

choices.text: Cobalt blue with trypan blue for corneal ulcer
Cobalt green with Rose Bengal stain for corneal opacity
Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer
Cobalt blue with lissamine green for corneal abrasion

questions.text: Which of the following accurately pairs the  diagnostic stain with the corneal condition it indicates? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer

 

This is the correct match. Fluorescein, when used with a cobalt blue light, stains areas of corneal epithelial loss, highlighting defects such as corneal ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobalt blue with trypan blue for corneal ulcer: Trypan blue is generally used in cataract surgery to stain the anterior capsule, not for diagnosing corneal ulcers.

 

Option B. Cobalt green with Rose Bengal stain for corneal opacity: Rose Bengal stain is actually used to detect damage to the eye's surface cells, particularly in cases of dry eye where these cells are more vulnerable. 

 

Option D. Cobalt blue with lissamine green for corneal abrasion: Lissamine green stains areas of cell loss or damage on the surface of the eye, such as in cases of corneal abrasion or dry eye. It’s used under white light rather than cobalt blue light.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fluorescein stain under cobalt blue light remains a standard and effective method for diagnosing corneal ulcers due to its ability to vividly highlight areas of epithelial loss.

questions.text: Curtain falling sign is indicative of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinal detachment

 

The curtain falling sign is a classic symptom of retinal detachment (RD), specifically rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. In this condition, a tear or hole develops in the retina, allowing fluid to pass behind it and separate the retina from the underlying tissue. As the detached portion of the retina falls forward, it creates the perception of a curtain or shadow moving across the visual field, hence the term "curtain falling sign".

 

 

Treatment: The treatment for retinal detachment involves three primary steps:

 

  1. Subretinal Fluid (SRF) Drainage: This step involves removing the fluid that has accumulated beneath the retina to allow for proper reattachment.
  2. Opposition of Retinal and Scleral Surfaces: This is achieved through:
    • Vitrectomy: Removing vitreous gel to facilitate retinal manipulation.
    • Scleral Buckling (Encirclage): Placing a band around the eye to indent the sclera and close the retinal tear.
  3. Closure of the Retinal Break: This is done using:
    • Laser Photocoagulation: Applying laser energy to create a scar that seals the break.
    • Cryopexy: Using intense cold to freeze and seal the tear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macular degeneration: This condition affects the central part of the retina (macula) and typically causes gradual vision loss or distortion in the central visual field, not a curtain-like shadow.

 

Option C. Optic atrophy: This refers to the degeneration of the optic nerve fibers and usually results in pale optic discs and decreased visual acuity, but does not cause a curtain-like visual phenomenon.

 

Option D. Acute anterior uveitis: This is inflammation of the front part of the uvea (iris and ciliary body) and typically causes pain, redness, and photophobia, but not a curtain-like visual symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

3 types of RD: Rhegmatogenous, Tractional and Exudative Retinal Detachment

 

1.   Rhegmatogenous Retinal Detachment:

  • Most common form, occurring when a tear or hole in the retina allows fluid to enter and accumulate under the retina, separating it from the underlying tissues.
  • Classical symptoms include visual flashes and floaters, which are due to the movement of the detached retina.
  • A "curtain falling" sign, where a section of the visual field appears to be shaded, is characteristic of this type.

 

2.  Tractional Retinal Detachment:

  • Occurs when fibrous or fibrovascular tissue, often resulting from proliferative diabetic retinopathy or other conditions, exerts traction on the retina, pulling it away from its underlying support tissue.

 

3.  Exudative Retinal Detachment:

  • Also known as serous retinal detachment, this type occurs without tears or breaks in the retina.
  • Fluid accumulates under the retina due to inflammation, injury, or vascular abnormalities causing leakage.

questions.text: What is the first step in the management of an 18-month-old child with both eyes deviated medially? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Refractive error testing

 

In children, who present with a convergent squint, the first step is to check the visual acuity and estimate the error of refraction.

 

  • When the child presents, the distant vision is recorded and atropine 1% eye ointment, 3 times a day, is prescribed for three days.
  • After 3 days, the error of refraction is estimated by retinoscopy.
  • Fundoscopy is done to rule out retinoblastoma, and any other pathology
  • The angle of squint is measured and full spectacle correction is ordered for constant use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forced ductions test: Used to check if the eye muscles move normally or are restricted, more relevant in cases where physical obstruction or muscle entrapment is suspected.

 

Option B. Examination under anesthesia: May be necessary for a comprehensive examination in uncooperative children, but it is not the first step.

 

Option D. Examination of fundus: Important for ruling out intraocular causes of squint such as retinoblastoma, but it follows the refractive assessment in priority.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first management step for a child presenting with a convergent squint is to test for refractive errors. This helps to identify any need for optical correction which might resolve or reduce the squint, thereby improving the visual development and alignment of the eyes.

questions.text: A person presents with complaints of blurry near vision that gets worse in dim light. The ray diagram shows parallel rays entering the eye and converging behind the retina. The focal point varies depending on lighting conditions. [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypermetropia

 

Explanation: 

 

The modified ray diagram would show parallel rays focusing behind the retina, characteristic of hypermetropia (farsightedness). This condition becomes more symptomatic in dim light because:

  • The pupil dilates in dim light, increasing spherical aberration
  • Accommodation mechanism struggles more in low light conditions
  • Symptoms worsen when the ciliary muscles fatigue

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presbyopia: While it also affects near vision, presbyopia is specifically related to aging of the lens and doesn't vary significantly with lighting conditions

 

Option B. Myopia: In myopia, rays focus in front of the retina, not behind it

 

Option C. Astigmatism: While astigmatism can cause blur, it produces multiple focal points due to irregular corneal curvature, not a single focal point behind the retina

 

Educational Objective:
