Understanding how different lighting conditions affect refractive errors is crucial for diagnosis. Hypermetropia often becomes more symptomatic in dim light due to pupillary changes and accommodative stress, which is an important clinical pearl for differential diagnosis of refractive errors.

questions.text: An intraocular lens was placed uneventfully in a young patient during cataract surgery. What should be done thereafter? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Never replaced

 

In the case of a successful and uneventful intraocular lens (IOL) implantation during cataract surgery, there is typically no need to replace the IOL. These lenses are designed to be permanent solutions that do not require routine replacement. Modern IOLs are made from durable materials that are meant to last a lifetime without degrading or causing adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IOL replaced every 10 years: There is no routine schedule for replacing IOLs as they are designed to last a lifetime.

 

Option C. Replaced when secondary cataract develops: Secondary cataract (or posterior capsule opacification) can often be treated with a simple laser procedure called a posterior capsulotomy, not by replacing the IOL.

 

Option D. Replaced when presbyopia develops: Presbyopia is related to the lens of the eye and loss of its elasticity, affecting near vision; IOLs implanted during cataract surgery do not correct presbyopia inherent to aging, but specific types of IOLs can be chosen to address presbyopia at the time of surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An IOL replacement (IOL exchange) may be done under the following conditions:

 

  • Incorrect IOL placed-Incorrect power or Incorrect Type
  • Posterior or anterior dislocation of IOL
  • Hyphema
  • Asymmetrical Haptic Placement
  • Sunset Syndrome
  • Lens-Bag Decentration

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of keratoconus? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haab's striae  

 

Haab’s striae are not a feature of Keratoconus. Haab's striae are seen in buphthalmos where the intraocular pressure is raised and the eyeball is enlarged as a whole. The enlarged cornea is associated with tears in Descemet's membrane called Haab's striae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Munson's sign: Directly associated with keratoconus. It is observed when the patient looks down, causing the lower eyelid to bulge out due to the cone-shaped cornea.

 

Option C. Irregular Astigmatism: A hallmark of keratoconus, resulting from the irregular thinning and bulging of the cornea.

 

Option D. Scissoring Reflex: This is a characteristic finding in keratoconus observed during retinoscopy due to the irregular shape of the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following signs may be elicited in keratoconus –

choices.text: Kinetic perimetry is used in quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma
In Static perimetry, stimulus intensity is held constant and moved centrally with detection
Visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it should have the corresponding optic nerve head abnormalities
Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot

questions.text: Which of these statements is true regarding perimetry? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot


Initial indications of glaucoma in perimetry involve a widespread narrowing of isopters and the appearance of a blockage within the blind spot.

 

Perimetry is a diagnostic test used to assess a person's visual field.

 

Static Perimetry: Traditional method involving fixed stimulus points presented on a static grid. Goldmann perimetry and Humphrey Visual Field Analyzer are common devices for static perimetry.

 

Kinetic Perimetry: Moving stimuli are used to determine the boundaries of the visual field. Useful for mapping the extent of peripheral vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Kinetic perimetry involves moving a stimulus across the visual field to map the boundaries of each isopter. It is not specifically used for quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma; static perimetry is more commonly used for this purpose

 

Option B: In static perimetry, various light spots of different intensities are presented in different locations but do not move across the visual field. The statement in B inaccurately describes kinetic perimetry

 

Option C: While optic nerve head abnormalities are a critical diagnostic feature of glaucoma, visual field defects can exist without clear corresponding optic nerve changes, especially in early or mild cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimetry is vital for early detection and monitoring of glaucoma. Generalized constriction of isopters and enlargement of the blind spot are key early signs that can indicate the presence of this eye condition.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with jaundice and bilateral pitting ankle edema. On eye examination, an ophthalmologist reports xanthelasma and corneal arcus. What next investigation is most appropriate to diagnose the underlying condition? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lipid profile

 

Explanation: 

 

The presence of xanthelasma and corneal arcus in a young patient with signs of liver dysfunction strongly suggests familial hyperlipidemia with possible liver involvement. A lipid profile would be the most appropriate next step because:

  • Xanthelasma and corneal arcus are cholesterol deposits, especially significant when present in young patients
  • Early onset suggests genetic/familial etiology
  • Associated liver dysfunction can occur in severe hyperlipidemia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum ceruloplasmin: While useful for Wilson's disease, there are no Kayser-Fleischer rings described, making this less relevant

 

Option B. Serum iron level: Would be more relevant in hemochromatosis, but doesn't explain the eye findings

 

Option C. Alpha 1 antitrypsin: While it can cause liver disease, it doesn't typically present with xanthelasma or corneal arcus

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of xanthelasma and corneal arcus in a young patient should prompt investigation for lipid disorders, especially when accompanied by signs of organ involvement. Early recognition and appropriate testing are crucial for managing familial hyperlipidemia and preventing complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis. What associated complication is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Scleromalacia perforans

 

  • Scleromalacia perforans is a complication of rheumatoid arthritis shown in the image.
  • It is a type of necrotizing scleritis without inflammation. Typically occurs in elderly females with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is characterized by the development of yellowish patch of melting sclera. The sclera melts due to obliteration of blood supply.
  • Episclera and conjunctiva often completely separate from the surrounding normal sclera.
  • Sequestrum of sclera becomes dead white in colour.
  • Eventually, sequestrum absorbs leaving behind a large punched-out area of thin sclera through which the uveal tissue shines. Spontaneous perforation is extremely rare.
  • Clinical features include pain, photophobia, and lacrimation. The affected eye appears red.
  • Medical management includes steroids and immunosuppressants.
  • In severe cases, surgical treatment by scleral patch graft may be done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ﻿﻿﻿Ciliary staphyloma:

  • It is used to describe the bulge of an area of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body.
  • Common causes include scleritis, developmental glaucoma, and end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma.
  • Another cause includes thinning of the sclera, secondary to perforating injury.

 

 

Option C. Coloboma:

  • It is a congenital anomaly, that develops due to a defect in the closure of the embryonic cleft.
  • It is characterized by poorly developed or deficient uveal tissue. The lens, choroid, and retina may also be involved.
  • The image below shows coloboma of the right eyelid.

 

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

  • It is usually seen in elderly patients.
  • If it involves the conjunctiva, it appears as a mass near the limbus. It can be pigmented or non-pigmented.
  • The choroid, iris, ciliary body, and eyelids can also develop the tumour.
  • The image below shows malignant melanoma of the conjunctiva.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleromalacia perforans is a severe ocular complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis characterized by a melting patch of sclera with exposure of underlying uveal tissue, typically managed with steroids, immunosuppressants, and potentially surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presents with photophobia and watering. Which of the following cannot be the cause? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction

 

Photophobia and watering in a 3-month-old child can be caused by various conditions. Here’s a closer look at each condition:

 

  • Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: This condition typically presents with excessive tearing (lacrimation) due to blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. However, it does not cause photophobia. Photophobia indicates sensitivity to light, which is not a feature of nasolacrimal duct obstruction.
  • Congenital entropion: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid, causing the eyelashes to rub against the cornea. This can lead to corneal abrasions, resulting in both photophobia and watering.
  • Congenital glaucoma: This is characterized by increased intraocular pressure, which can lead to a triad of symptoms: photophobia, lacrimation, and blepharospasm (eyelid twitching). It is a serious condition that requires prompt medical attention.
  • Congenital distichiasis: This condition involves an extra row of eyelashes, which can irritate the cornea, leading to corneal abrasions. This irritation can cause both photophobia and lacrimation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: As explained, this condition causes lacrimation but not photophobia. This makes it the to the question of which condition cannot cause photophobia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction is associated with excessive tearing but does not cause photophobia. Other conditions like congenital entropion, congenital glaucoma, and congenital distichiasis can cause both photophobia and watering due to corneal involvement and irritation.

questions.text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Central retinal vein occlusion

 

  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) is also known as "90-" or "100-day glaucoma" due to its typical development 3 months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO).
  • NVG results from the occlusion of the central retinal vein, causing significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis.
  • Recurrent hemorrhages are common, and neovascularization of the retina and optic disc develop.
  • The retina undergoes pigmentary and atrophic changes.
  • NVG occurs in three stages:
    1. Pre-glaucomatous stage - stage of rubeosis iridis i.e. neovascularisation on the surface of the iris.
    2. Open-angle glaucoma stage - due to the formation of a pretrabecular neovascular membrane.
    3. Secondary angle closure glaucoma— due to goniosynechiae resulting from contracture of the neovascular membrane (zipper-angle closure).

 

 

  • Treatment of NVG is usually frustrating.
    • Pan-retinal photocoagulation may be carried out to prevent further neovascularization.
    • Medical therapy and conventional filtration surgery are usually not effective in controlling the IOP.
    • Artificial filtration shunt (valved/unvalved) may control the IOP.
  • Serious complications of central retinal vein occlusion are cystoid degeneration of the macula, optic atrophy, and hemorrhagic or neovascular glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Eale’s disease: Eales disease, also known as "primary retinal periphlebitis" or "periphlebitis retinae," is a rare inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the blood vessels in the retina of the eye. It was first described by the British ophthalmologist Henry Eales in 1880, and the condition was subsequently named after him.

 

Eales disease typically occurs in young adults, often males, and is more prevalent in certain regions, including India. The exact cause of Eales disease is not well understood, but it is believed to have an immunological basis. Some theories suggest that it may be related to immune system dysfunction, possibly triggered by an underlying infection or other factors.

 

The main features of Eales disease include:

 

  1. Retinal Vasculitis: Inflammation of the small blood vessels (veins) in the retina. This can lead to retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and swelling, which can affect vision.
  2. Neovascularization: New, abnormal blood vessels may develop as a response to the damaged retinal vessels. These abnormal vessels can be fragile and prone to bleeding, leading to further vision problems.
  3. Vitreous Hemorrhage:
  4. Retinal Detachment: In some cases, Eales disease can lead to tractional retinal detachment.

 

The symptoms of Eales disease can vary and may include blurred vision, floaters, and reduced visual acuity. Diagnosis is typically made through a thorough clinical examination, which may include the use of imaging techniques like fundus fluorescein angiography to visualize the areas of capillary non-perfusion, leakage (suggestive of neovascularisation or macular edema).

 

The treatment of Eales disease aims to control inflammation, prevent or treat complications, and preserve or improve vision. Treatment options may include systemic or local corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and macular edema, intravitreal Anti VEGF injection for macular edema, laser photocoagulation therapy to target abnormal blood vessels, and in some cases, surgical intervention (pars plana vitrectomy) to address complications like retinal detachment and vitreous haemorrhage. The specific treatment plan will depend on the severity of the disease and the individual patient's needs.

 

It's important for individuals with Eales disease to receive ongoing care and follow-up with an ophthalmologist to monitor their condition and manage any potential complications. Causative association with tuberculosis is present and patient needs to be evaluated for TB and AKT may be initiated where indicated.

 

Option C. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is a medical condition that occurs when the central retinal artery becomes blocked or narrowed. This blockage results in a sudden and severe loss of vision in the affected eye. CRAO is considered a medical emergency because it can lead to permanent vision loss if not treated promptly.

 

Common causes and risk factors of central retinal artery occlusion include:

 

  1. Atherosclerosis: The most common cause of CRAO is atherosclerosis.
  2. Embolism:
  3. Giant cell arteritis: This is a condition in which the arteries, including the central retinal artery, become inflamed. It primarily affects older individuals and can result in CRAO. GCA is an emergency requiring prompt initiation of systemic steroids to prevent the fellow eye from developing CRAO.
  4. Vasculitis: Occlusive inflammation of the blood vessels can lead to occlusion of the central retinal artery.

 

Symptoms of central retinal artery occlusion may include:

 

  1. Sudden, painless, and severe vision loss in one eye.
  2. The affected eye may appear pale or whitened (retinal pallor).
  3. RAPD.
  4. Cherry-red spot: Due to the contrast between the well-oxygenated macula and the poorly oxygenated surrounding retina.

 

Treatment options may include:

 

  1. Ocular massage: to dislodge the embolus causing the blockage.
  2. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Breathing pure oxygen in a pressurized chamber can increase oxygen delivery to the retina and may be considered in some cases.
  3. Carbogen inhalation therapy or rebreathing into a paper bag – Resultant hypercarbemia causes vasodilation which may help to dislodge the embolus and restore blood flow.
  4. Reducing intraocular pressure – by means of Anterior Chamber paracentesis or systemic acetazolamide.
  5. Surgical intervention: Optic Nerve Sheath fenestration surgery.
  6. Thrombolytic therapy: In some situations, clot-dissolving medications may be used.

 

Option D. Steroid-induced glaucoma:

 

  • Description: Glaucoma resulting from prolonged use of corticosteroids.
  • Mechanism: Steroids can increase IOP by reducing the outflow of aqueous humor.
  • Symptoms: Gradual loss of peripheral vision, halos around lights, headache, eye pain.
  • Treatment: Reducing or discontinuing steroid use, using IOP-lowering medications.

  • Note: Steroid-induced glaucoma is not associated with neovascularization or termed as 100-day glaucoma.

     

Educational Objective:

 

Neovascular glaucoma, known as "100-day glaucoma," typically develops about three months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) due to significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis leading to neovascularization.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is diagnosed with amblyopia in one eye, what will be the best management?(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occlusion therapy

 

The best treatment for an amblyopic 3-year-old is occlusion therapy.

Amblyopia is a primary visual pathway abnormality of the eye that affects spatial visual processing during development.

 

The period during which acuity of an amblyopic eye can be improved: usually up to 7–8 years in strabismic amblyopia and into the teens for anisometropic amblyopia with good binocular function.

 

Organic disease needs to be excluded before commencing treatment for amblyopia.

 

(i) The most effective treatment: Occlusion of the normal eye, to encourage use of the amblyopic eye. The regimen, depends on the age of the patient and the density of amblyopia.

  • The younger the patient, the more rapid the improvement but the greater the risk of inducing amblyopia in the normal eye. Thus, it is very important to monitor VA regularly in both eyes during treatment.
  • The better the VA at the start of occlusion, the shorter the duration required, usually.
  • If there has been no improvement after 6 months of effective occlusion, further treatment is unlikely to be successful.
  • Patch occlusion is likely to produce a quicker response than atropine.
  • The single greatest barrier to improvement: Poor compliance.

 

(ii) Alternative method: Penalization, in which vision in the normal eye is blurred with atropine.

  • It may work best for mild–moderate amblyopia (6/24 or better), especially when due to anisometropic hypermetropia.
  • Penalization offers the particular advantage of compliance in terms of lesser likelihood of being removed by the child and less psychosocial problems.

 

Occlusion therapy -

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Observation: Observation alone is not recommended for amblyopia as active treatment is necessary to improve visual outcomes during the critical period of visual development.

 

Option C. Refraction with near addition: While appropriate refractive correction is important, it is not sufficient as the sole treatment for amblyopia. Occlusion therapy or penalization is needed to stimulate the amblyopic eye.

 

Option D. Laser surgery: Laser surgery is not an appropriate treatment for amblyopia. It is primarily used for correcting refractive errors or specific eye conditions like retinal issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for a 3-year-old child with amblyopia is occlusion therapy, which involves covering the normal eye to encourage use and development of the amblyopic eye. Regular monitoring and compliance are essential for successful treatment.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pterygium

 

The likely diagnosis, based on the above image, is pterygium.

  • Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea.
  • It is a wing-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea from either side within the interpalpebral fissure.
  • It is more common in people living in hot climates, and a response to prolonged effect of environmental factors such as exposure to sun (ultraviolet rays), dry heat, high wind and abundance of dust.

 

Clinical features:

  • It is more common in elderly males doing outdoor work.
  • It may be unilateral or bilateral.
  • It presents as a triangular fold of conjunctiva encroaching the cornea in the area of palpebral aperture, usually on the nasal side but may also occur on the temporal side.
  • Deposition of iron seen sometimes in corneal epithelium anterior to advancing head of pterygium is called stocker's line.
  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Irritation and grittiness are caused by a dellen – localized drying of tear film.
  • Cosmesis may be a significant problem.
  • Visual disturbances occur when it encroaches the pupillary area or due to corneal astigmatism induced due to fibrosis in the regressive stage.
  • Diplopia may occur due to limitation of ocular movements.
  • PARTS OF A PTERYGIUM:

 

A fully developed pterygium consists of three parts

  1. Head (apical part present on the cornea),
  2. Neck (limbal part), and
  3. Body (scleral part) extending between limbus and the canthus.

 

Differences between pterygium and pseudopterygium

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: A yellowish, benign growth on the conjunctiva that does not encroach onto the cornea.

 

Option B. Concretions: Small, yellowish-white deposits on the conjunctiva, often associated with chronic conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Bitot's spots: Foamy, whitish lesions on the conjunctiva, typically associated with vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium is characterized by a wing-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea, commonly seen in people exposed to prolonged environmental factors like UV rays and dust. The treatment includes surgical removal and techniques to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which is the most common intraocular malignancy in adults? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Choroidal metastasis

 

Explanation:

 

The most common intraocular malignancy in adults is choroidal metastasis.

 

Metastatic tumors to the eye, particularly to the choroid, are more common than primary intraocular malignancies. These metastases usually originate from primary cancers in other parts of the body, such as the breast or lung. The choroid is a vascular layer of the eye that provides a conducive environment for metastatic cells to thrive.

 

The most common primary intraocular malignancy is choroidal melanoma. Choroidal melanoma is the most common primary intraocular cancer in adults, but overall, metastases are more prevalent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: This is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children, not adults.

 

Option B. Choroidal melanoma: While this is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults, it is less common than metastatic tumors overall.

 

Option C. Uveal melanoma: This term encompasses melanomas of the choroid, ciliary body, and iris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Most common intraocular malignancy in adults - Choroidal melanoma
  • Most common primary intraorbital malignancy in adults -Capillary Hemangioma.
  • Most common primary intraocular malignancy in children – Retinoblastoma
  • Most common intraorbital malignancy in children – Rhabdomyosarcoma

questions.text: A patient with a history of facial trauma, presented with diplopia, epistaxis, and restricted eye movements. Looking at the CT image given below, what will be your diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Blow-out fracture

 

The given clinical scenario plus CT image suggests a blowout fracture.

 

Orbital blowout fractures:

  • Result from trauma to the orbit.
  • Mainly involve orbital floor and medial wall.
  • Clinical signs:
  • Periocular swelling (early stage)
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • The muscle restriction is confirmed with a positive “forced duction test”.

 

Forced Duction Test:

  • It is used to determine whether the absence of movement of eye is due to paralysis of extraocular muscles or due to mechanical obstruction.
  • To perform this test, anaesthetized conjunctiva, is grasped with forceps.
  • Now, an attempt is made to move the eyeball in the direction where the movement is restricted.
  • POSITIVE forced duction test: If it is due to mechanical obstruction, it will not be possible to move the eyeball.
  • NEGATIVE forced duction test: If it is due to paralytic squint, eyeball can move.
  • Investigations:
    • Waters view in x-ray shows a teardrop opacity.
    • CT scan is used for confirmation of diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Initial management is to prevent further injury to the globe.
    • Surgical indications:
    • Enophthalmos
    • Diplopia
    • Ocular motility disorder
    • Immediate repair indicated if oculocardiac reflex or significant enophthalmos is present.
    • Delayed repair is done within 2 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le-Fort fracture: Involves fractures of the maxillary bones and may present with midfacial mobility, but not typically with the specific signs of blow-out fractures.

 

Option B. Fracture maxilla: May involve the upper jaw but not specifically associated with the orbital floor fractures seen in blow-out fractures.

 

Option C. Fracture zygomatic: Involves the cheekbone and can cause facial asymmetry and infraorbital anesthesia, but typically does not cause the specific signs of a blow-out fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A blow-out fracture, typically resulting from orbital trauma, is characterized by periocular swelling, subcutaneous emphysema, enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. The diagnosis is confirmed by a CT scan showing the characteristic teardrop sign.

questions.text: In the medical management of glaucoma, drugs which decrease the intraocular pressure are indicated. Which of the following drugs decreases intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral flow? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Latanoprost

 

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug used to lower intraocular pressure.
  • It works by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
  • Latanoprost is a prodrug that is activated during its passage through the cornea.
  • It stimulates prostanoid receptors on ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases.
  • Matrix metalloproteinases increase uveoscleral outflow.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker that decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production. It does not significantly affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine: A miotic agent that increases trabecular outflow but does not have a significant effect on uveoscleral outflow. It works by constricting the pupil and contracting the ciliary muscle.

 

Option D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide): These drugs decrease intraocular pressure by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, thereby reducing the production of aqueous humor. They do not affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, making it an effective treatment option for glaucoma.

choices.text: When he complains of decrease in vision

questions.text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a dilated fundus examination for him? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediately

 

Immediate dilated fundus examination is recommended for individuals diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, as early detection of diabetic retinopathy is crucial for preventing vision loss. Screening at diagnosis is essential because diabetic retinopathy can be asymptomatic in its early stages, yet still pose a risk of significant damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Before his 50th birthday: While this is within five years of diagnosis, immediate examination is preferred for immediate intervention and management.

 

Option C. After his 50th birthday: Delaying the examination could lead to unnoticed progression of diabetic retinopathy and potentially irreversible damage.

 

Option D. When he complains of decrease in vision: Waiting for symptoms such as decreased vision can result in delayed diagnosis of diabetic retinopathy, at which point some damage may be irreversible.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought by his mother with complaints of inability to open the eyes in light and excessive watering. The clinical picture is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Congenital glaucoma

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea suggests congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.
     

 

  • Other features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.

 

  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy

 

  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In ophthalmia neonatorum, there will be inflammation of the conjunctiva. Clinical presentation includes conjunctival discharge, hyperaemia, chemosis, swollen eyelids, tender eyeball.

 

 

Option C. In mucopolysaccharidosis, there will be bilateral cloudy cornea.

 

 

Option D. In cataract, there will be opacification of lens presenting as whitish reflex/ leukocoria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CAUSES OF LEUKOCORIA:

questions.text: Oil droplet cataract is seen in?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Galactosemia

 

Explanation:

 

Oil droplet cataract is characteristically seen in galactosemia. This type of cataract presents as a central oil droplet appearance in the lens, which is a distinctive finding in patients with this metabolic disorder. Galactosemia is a genetic condition that affects the body's ability to process the sugar galactose properly, leading to its accumulation in various tissues, including the lens of the eye, resulting in the oil droplet appearance.

 

 

In galactosemia, early detection and dietary management can help prevent or reduce the severity of cataracts and other complications. The mnemonic to remember this association is that "oil" and "gallons" both start with "gal," linking oil droplet cataract to galactosemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myotonic dystrophy: The cataract seen in myotonic dystrophy is typically a Christmas tree cataract, characterized by multi-colored, glittering, needle-shaped crystals within the lens.

 

 

Option C. Wilson's disease: This condition is associated with a sunflower cataract, where deposits of copper cause a characteristic sunburst pattern in the lens.

 

 

Option D. Diabetes mellitus: Diabetic patients are more likely to develop snowflake cataracts, which are characterized by flake-like opacities within the lens.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oil droplet cataract is a distinctive feature seen in patients with galactosemia, a genetic disorder that impairs the metabolism of galactose, leading to characteristic changes in the lens of the eye.

 

Note – Oil droplet reflex on retinoscopy seen in - Keratoconus

questions.text: What is the indication of this procedure? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Keratoconus

 

The given image shows the placement of Intacs, which is done for keratoconus.

  • Keratoconus is a non-inflammatory condition of the axial cornea.
  • Pathognomonic features include central or paracentral thinning of the cornea and apical protrusion of the anterior cornea.
  • Defective vision, progressive myopia, and irregular astigmatism are common clinical features.
  • Light sensitivity and ocular irritation may also be present.
  • Clinical signs: 
    1. Scissor reflex (yawning reflex) on retinoscopy is the earliest sign.
    2. Oil droplet reflex is seen with distant direct ophthalmoscopy.
    3. Fleischer’s ring (Epithelial iron deposits) and Vogt lines (Oblique stromal striae) (Image given below) are seen on slit lamp examination.
      Note: Kayser –fleischer ring is due to deposition of the copper and is seen in Wilson disease and chalcosis.
    4. Rizzuti's sign, a bright reflection from the nasal area of the limbus when light is directed to the limbus temporal area.
    5. Munson’s sign (localized bulging of the lower lid on looking down) is positive in keratoconus. (Image given below)
  • Complications include acute hydrops due to rupture of Descemet's membrane.

 

 

Vogt’s line:

 

Vogt’s triad

 

Occurs centrally in a patient with keratoconus

  • Vertical stromal/ Descemet’s membrane lines.
  • Stress lines due to stretching and thinning.
  • Disappear with globe pressure.

 

 

  • The earliest way to detect any curvature disease of the cornea including keratoconus is topography (mapping of the point-to-point thickness of the cornea).
  • The severity of the condition is graded based on keratometry.
  • Treatment: Declining visual acuity may not be corrected by glasses due to irregular astigmatism.
    1. In early cases:
      • Contact lenses (rigid gas permeable)
      • Intacs, the intracorneal ring segments (flatten the cornea)
    2. In later stages: Penetrating keratoplasty may be required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vogt's limbal girdle: Vogt's limbal girdle is a benign, age-related condition characterized by white, chalky deposits at the limbus. It is not treated with Intacs.

 

Option C. Keratoglobus: Keratoglobus is a condition characterized by a generalized thinning and globular protrusion of the entire cornea. It is not typically treated with Intacs.

 

Option D. Corneal dystrophy: Corneal dystrophies are a group of genetic, often progressive, eye disorders in which abnormal material accumulates in the cornea. Treatment varies and does not typically involve Intacs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The placement of Intacs is an indicated treatment for keratoconus, a condition characterized by the thinning and protrusion of the cornea leading to progressive myopia and irregular astigmatism.
